newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Britain to present BSE plan to EU in February.
newsitem.headline: Britain to present BSE plan to EU in February.

text.p: British Farm Minister Douglas Hogg said on Monday that Britain will present plans to the European Union in early February to exempt herds free of mad cow disease from a worldwide EU ban on British beef exports.

The EU imposed the export ban in March 1996 after the British government caused consumer panic by disclosing that madcow disease -- Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) -- can be transmitted to humans as Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease (CJD).

Hogg said the British parliament will on Tuesday debate the plans, previously expected late January and which, if accepted, would be the first step in easing the export ban following a compromise reached at an EU summit in Florence last June.

"We wouldn't want to put forward a working document until the House of Commons has approved the Orders. That'll be tomorrow night. We'll be putting forward the working document I anticipate in early February," Hogg told Reuters.
Hogg, in Brussels for a half-day meeting of EU farm ministers, denied that the certified herd scheme would allow Northern Irish exporters to grab Scottish markets.
"I don't think that's the proper way to look at it," he said. "We...will be putting forward proposals, which are UK-wide both in terms of definition and...application."
"But it is certainly true and the point has been made before that Northern Ireland is well placed to take advantage of the certified herds scheme," he added.
This is because Northern Irish herds are mainly grass-fed and their details and movements are recorded on a computerised system.
Scottish herds are not yet recorded on a computer data base while English and Welsh herds have in addition been more exposed to contaminated feed containing meat and bone meal.

After Britain has presented the working document, it will be examined by various EU scientific and veterinary committees before the European Commission takes a final decision -- a process which could take months.
